entry.title: Presentation: Poster Presentations Workshop (Skills for Student Success)

media:group.media:title: Presentation: Poster Presentations Workshop (Skills for Student Success)
media:group.media:description:
Recording of an online session dealing with preparing scientific posters. The audience for this presentation was a group of senior undergraduate students, who would be presenting their own research at the end of that term.
In the presentation, I deal with tips for good visual presentation of your content, we critique some sample of posters, and we go over some tips for the actual verbal portion of the poster presentation.

entry.title: Preparing Your Work Area for Culture Work

media:group.media:title: Preparing Your Work Area for Culture Work
media:group.media:description:
If you have to wipe down your work area with 70% ethanol, then this video is for you.
This video mostly deals with preparing the work area for Cell and Tissue Culture work, but the first part is relevant to preparing for any Microbiology or Molecular Biology work as well.

media:group.media:title: Colony PCR Protocol (BIOL310)
media:group.media:description:
In this video, I walk you through the procedure of screening bacterial colonies for your gene of interest using Colony PCR. In the process, I also introduce the concept of a PCR Master Mix, which will simplify and speed up your work.
0:00 - Introduction 0:40 - Preparing bacterial samples for use as template DNA 2:26 - Preparation of a PCR Master Mix 5:20 - Completing the PCR reaction setup

media:group.media:title: Bacterial Transformation by Heat Shock (BIOL310)
media:group.media:description:
In this video, I walk you through a shortened version of a protocol of chemical transformation - commonly known as "heat shock". This protocol starts with the preparation of chemically competent cells, before completing the actual transformation.
Please note that the very short treatment in CaCl2 in this procedure will yield enough cells capable of transformation to demonstrate the concept in a teaching lab, but will not yield transformation efficiency that is sufficient for research purposes.
0:00 - Introduction 0:41 - Preparing chemically competent cells 2:20 - The actual transformation procedure, including "heat shock" 3:33 - Recovery phase 4:30 - Plating

media:group.media:title: Concept: How does Spectrophotometry Work?
media:group.media:description: The aim of this video, is to demonstrate the basic principle behind how spectrophotometers are used to measure solutes in samples. We go over what Transmittance and Absorbance actually look like, without getting technical or looking at any mathematical formulas.

entry.title: Lab Skills: How to Turn a Curve into a Straight Line

media:group.media:title: Lab Skills: How to Turn a Curve into a Straight Line
media:group.media:description: I often joke with my students that I became a Biologist because I hated Calculus, and thus I don't like dealing with curves on my graphs - I prefer straight lines. In this video, I show you how to use semilog paper to turn exponential curves into straight lines.

media:group.media:title: Common Problems in Calculating Dilutions
media:group.media:description:
The process of preparing solutions often involves the use of a deceptively simple formula. In this video, I show you how to avoid some of the most common errors that are made by students using this formula.
0:00 - Introduction 0:52 - Problem #1 (C-what?, V-what?) 1:45 - Let's visualize this problem 4:02 - Applying what you've learned 11:15 - Problem #2 ("plug & play") 12:34 - Converting the units 13:30 - The correct way to do this 14:52 - Problem #3 (not dealing with complexity) 15:36 - Let's visualize this problem 16:21 - Common error made in such cases 17:10 - The correct way to approach this 21.13 - Don't forget about the water (solvent)

entry.title: Lab Skills: Loading an Agarose Gel

media:group.media:title: Lab Skills: Loading an Agarose Gel
media:group.media:description:
Do your hands shake when you try loading your samples? Is someone standing behind you and assessing your performance? You could probably use some advice...
In this video, I give you a few quick tips that should help you improve your technique.

media:group.media:title: Determining DNA Concentration (BIOL310)
media:group.media:description:
In this video, I walk you through the process of determining the DNA concentration using absorbance measurements at 260nm. We then combine those with a reading at 280nm to get idea of the level of purity of the DNA in our sample.
0:00 - Introduction 0:32 - Preparing dilutions of our samples 2:13 - Selecting an appropriate blank 2:33 - Taking absorbance readings 3:23 - Calculating the concentration and level of purification

entry.title: Lab Skills: Preparing an Agarose Gel

media:group.media:title: Lab Skills: Preparing an Agarose Gel
media:group.media:description:
Many teaching labs don't actually give students a chance to do this - mostly due to time constraints, and also due to the use of a potential mutagen like Ethidium Bromide.
But, it is something you will need to be able to do if you're ever working in a molecular biology research lab. So, he it is: a quick walk-through of all the steps involved.

entry.title: Lab Skills: Measuring the size of a DNA fragment

media:group.media:title: Lab Skills: Measuring the size of a DNA fragment
media:group.media:description: You can use your gel to guess at the size of your DNA, or you can actually measure it. This video shows you how to do it right.

entry.title: Lab Skills: So Many Ways to Mix Your Sample...

media:group.media:title: Lab Skills: So Many Ways to Mix Your Sample...
media:group.media:description: Depending on what it's trying to accomplish, your protocol may ask you to mix your sample tube in one of many ways. Here are just a few common examples.

media:group.media:title: Metric Conversions - Practice 2
media:group.media:description:
Second "Rapid-fire" session. I present you with 5 questions and ask you to make the conversions in 5 sec. This is meant to be a bit of a challenge - it's doable if you're doing it in your head, it's harder if you're working on paper.
At the end of the 5 sec, I work through the answer step-by-step.
If you're just starting out and feel like you need more time, then feel free to pause the video until you complete your answers.

media:group.media:title: Metric Conversions - Practice 1
media:group.media:description:
First "Rapid-fire" session. I present you with 5 questions and ask you to make the conversions in 5 sec. This is meant to be a bit of a challenge - it's doable if you're doing it in your head, it's harder if you're working on paper.
At the end of the 5 sec, I work through the answer step-by-step.
If you're just starting out and feel like you need more time, then feel free to pause the video until you complete your answers.

entry.title: Lab Skills: A Common Micropipetting Mistake

media:group.media:title: Lab Skills: A Common Micropipetting Mistake
media:group.media:description: A micropipettor is only as accurate as the person using it. Poor technique leads to poor results.
